question: There are elms, [MASK], limes, and silvery willows in parklike groups.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: There are benches along the rounded walksâwhich enlarge themselves here and there to rondels or to trim playgrounds for the children and to spacious planes of grass on which are growing old and well-formed trees with deep pendant crowns, revealing only a short stretch of trunk above the grass.
next_sentence: I find great pleasure in this carefully-groomed park, in which I could not wander more undisturbed, if it were my own.

question: ThereâI have told the story of the clinicâagainst my own [MASK] resolution.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
next_sentence: May the reader forgive this lengthy digression and return with me to the chase in the hunting-grounds which we had interrupted.

question: This [MASK] is neither forest nor parkâit is an enchanted gardenânothing less.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Out of this chaos of undergrowth and ground thicket the wild vine and the wild hop-plant go gyrating up in spirals, draping broad-leaved garlands upon the trees and even in winter clinging to the trunks with tendrils which resemble hard and unbreakable wire.
next_sentence: I will stoutly defend this termâeven though it refers to a poor, limited, and even crippled bit of nature, the glories of which may be exhausted with a few simple botanical names.

question: His head [MASK] forward and to one side, his body stretches and extends itself.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: His short bobbed tail begins to wave furiously.
next_sentence: He jumps hither and thither, and the next moment, with his nose still glued to the ground, he goes darting off.

question: He is then obsessed by a masculine mood and [MASK], and scorns all feminine touches.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: That he ignores all tendernesses at present is due not only to his disillusion and disappointment, but also to the fact that he has no interest for such fondlings when in a state of movement, that is, a state of movement co-ordinated with mine.
next_sentence: But an immediate change takes place as soon as I sit down.

question: These pickets are rather high, and he groans a little in his flight through the [MASK] out of fear lest he hurt himself.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: He comes back when I actually do turn towards the left, accompanies me, snorting deeply, and ejaculating short, confused high notes which seem to arise from the tremendous tension in his interior, as I walk along the fence of the garden, and then he begins to jump back and forth over the pickets of the adjacent public park.
next_sentence: He makes these leaps impelled by a kind of desperate gaiety, scornful of all hard facts, and also to bribe me, to work upon my sympathies by his cleverness.

question: He is [MASK] by blind impulses hither and thither in the darkness, through the yard and the gardenâhe runs from place to placeâand waits.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: His nocturnal rest is therefore dismembered and without unity.
next_sentence: He waits for the recurrent visit of the local watchman with the lantern, the heavy thud of whose footfall he accompanies against his own better knowledge with a terrible burst of heralding barks.

question: And on both sides there is an [MASK] button affixed to the rail.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Double steps of wood for the coming and the departing traveller lead down the escarpment on both sides into the bed of the river and to the landing-places.
next_sentence: A man appears on the other bank, stands still and peers across the water.

question: Bashanâs mobile little body, through which life pulsates so swiftly and [MASK], has been, so to speak, exhausted with restâand there can be no thought of sleep.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: But I believe that the torture of this nightly vigil is mild, compared to that which Bashan must endure in the broad of day, particularly when the weather is fair, be it winter or summer, when the sun lures into the open, and the desire for violent motion tugs in every muscle, and his master, without whom, of course, there can be no real enjoyment, persistently refuses to leave his seat behind the glass door.
next_sentence: Up he comes to the terrace in front of my door, drops himself in the gravel with a sob which comes from the very depths of his being, and lays his head upon his paws, turning up his eyes with a martyrâs expression towards heaven.

question: He was there, no denying itâthe idealism of his [MASK] had drawn him back to the world of potato-parings.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Two days heavy with care went by, and then Anastasia reported that she had received tidings from Huglfing that Lux had appeared at the parental farm an hour and a half ago.
next_sentence: And in lonely one-day marches, facing all kinds of wind and weather, he had covered the twenty kilometres which he had once travelled between the wheels of the farm wagon.

question: Then he reverts to his four [MASK], and is no better off than before.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: There he stands on three legs, melancholy and contemplativeâthe slave of a habit, whether urged by Nature or not.
next_sentence: Dumbly he gazes aloft into the branches of a group of ash-trees.

question: The answer, communicated from some [MASK] quarter, was to the effect that the health of the patient was as good as could be expected under the circumstancesâcircumstances which, for good reasons or for bad, one did not trouble to designate more clearly.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: I did not fail to make inquiries by telephone during the interval of waiting.
next_sentence: As soon as the day arrived on which I had taken Bashan to the veterinary institution, and the week was up, I once more made my way to the place.

question: If you chance to make a bullâs-eye, it [MASK] open and a tiny figure comes outâsay a milkmaid or a soldier.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: The ferryman, I repeat, comes outâand in his walk there is something which suggests that he has been set in motion directly by the pressure upon the push buttonâjust as one may shoot at a door in a tiny hut among the targets in the shooting-galleries.
next_sentence: Without showing the slightest sign of undue haste the ferryman walks with swinging arms through his little garden, crosses the footpath, descends the wooden steps to the river, pushes off the ferry, and holds the rudder whilst the pulley runs along the taut wire, and the boat is driven across by the current.

question: What would have happened had he [MASK] the bird?
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: This is sufficient for Bashanâs bliss; his wish and his will go no farther.
next_sentence: Nothing, I assure you, absolutely nothing.

question: And yet she is horribly afraid of the ram, who takes on huge and majestic proportions on account of the thickness of his wool and who refuses to be bullied and does whatever he [MASK].
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: She is constantly crouching low, propping her hands upon her knees and shouting with all her might in a cacophonous voice.
next_sentence: Whenever Bashanâs appearance causes a panic among the sheep, the child invariably raises its hideous outcry, and these panics occur quite regularly and quite contrary to Bashanâs intentionsâfor, if you could peer into his inmost soul, you would discover that sheep are a matter of absolute indifference to him.

question: These trees are of the species of the ashâa tree which [MASK] dampness as few others do.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: In these openings the Old Ones now tower, half privately, half publicly, their naked branches loaded with snow or bedizened with their small-leafed, late-sprouting foliage.
next_sentence: This quality at the same time offers a very significant commentary upon the essential peculiarity of our strip of country.

question: New and beautifully lacquered engines hurry to and fro on their trial trips, a steam siren occasionally lets its heady howl be heard, a dull, [MASK] pother makes the air quiver from time to time, and from the throats of several stacks the smoke creams darkly forth.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: The tall windows of this great brick shed glow through the darkness at all hours of the night.
next_sentence: This, however, is driven away by a kindly-disposed wind towards the distant tracts of woods, so that it seldom rolls across the river.

question: All this has not ceased to exert a magic influence upon me, even though the [MASK], for many a year, has been as a daily haunt to me.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: And then again there are sinkages in the groundâmere gravel-pits along the slopes and bottoms of which only a few willow shoots and a little dry sage manage to flourish.
next_sentence: In some way I am fantastically moved and touched by all this, for example, by the massed foliage of the ash-trees, which reminds me somehow of the contours of huge bulls.

question: They are [MASK] in an air of forlorn disquietude and neglect.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: They have stood here far too long, giving a name to adumbrations of streets in which no one cares to live, and they have been singled out to bear the stigmata of disappointment, fiasco, and arrested development to which they give public expression.
next_sentence: Nothing has been done for their upkeep nor for their renewal, and the weather and the sun have played havoc with them.

question: And also in winter when all the gravel is [MASK] with snow and soft and smooth, so that one may walk upon it in oneâs rubber overshoes, and when the river goes shooting black between the pale frost-bound shores and the cry of hundreds of fresh-water gulls fills the air from morning to evening.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: I have looked upon it at all hours and at all seasons; in autumn when the chemical smell of the fading leaves fills the air, when the white legions of the thistle-down have all been blown to the winds, when the great beeches of the Kurgarten spread a rust-coloured carpet of leaves about them on the meadows, and when afternoons dripping with gold merge into theatrically romantic twilights with the crescent moon swimming in the skies, with a milky brew of mist hovering over the levels and the afterglow of the sunset smouldering through the black silhouettes of the trees.
next_sentence: Nevertheless the easiest and most familiar intercourse with this landscape is during the mild months, when no special equipment in the way of defensive clothing is necessary, and one may go for a quick stroll for a quarter of an hour, betwixt and between two showers of rain, and, in passing, bend aside the branch of a black alder tree and cast a look into the wandering waves.

question: The river itself lies before us green and streaked with [MASK] and full of liquid roarings.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: We are now within the zone of the river.
next_sentence: It is actually only a great mountain torrent.

question: He waits for the paling of the heavens, the crowing of the cock in the near-by nursery-garden, the stir of the morning wind in the trees, and for the unlocking of the [MASK] entrance, so that he may slip in and warm himself at the white-tiled range.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I

question: Both of them are dreamily and [MASK] lapped in forgetfulness and decay.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Yes, it fitted, it âworked out!â We were wandering in the street which had been called âShakespeare.â  These signboards befit the streets which justify their metallic existence, and these streets the signboards which give them a local habitation and a name.
next_sentence: They pursue their way through the wood which they have invadedâbut the wood refuses to rest.

question: Thus in the suburban, semi-rural solitude of this region, the whisperings of contemplative nature mingle with those of human [MASK].
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: This, however, is driven away by a kindly-disposed wind towards the distant tracts of woods, so that it seldom rolls across the river.
next_sentence: Over all lies the blank-eyed freshness of the morning hour.

question: On one occasion, however, something quite contrary [MASK], something perverse and incomprehensibleâsomething still more extraordinary and unpleasant than the panic.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Have I given them any cause for this?
next_sentence: One of the sheep, quite an ordinary specimen of its kind, of average size and average sheepish visage, with a small upward curving mouth which appeared to smile and gave an expression of almost mocking stupidity to its face, seemed to be spellbound and fascinated by Bashan and came to join him.

question: He has reached the ultimate limit and no longer has a single [MASK] as to what he shall do with himself.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Then he stands motionless, in stark abstraction.
next_sentence: Under such circumstances as these, he has recourse to something extreme.

question: This dream-life was all too clearly an artificial substitute for the real chase, the real hunt, and was prepared for him by his nature, because in his common life with me, the happiness of unrestrained movement in the open did not devolve upon him in that measure which his blood and his [MASK] demanded.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: That this had a disturbing and distracting effect upon me need surprise no one, for, first of all, it was eerie, and then it stirred and burdened my conscience.
next_sentence: This came home to me very strongly, but as it was not to be altered, it was necessary that my moral disquietude should be dispelled by an appeal to other and higher interests.

question: With one wing [MASK] wide open and with its head drawn aside to the very limit of its neck, the pheasant lay in the grass and screamed, screamed without a single pauseâa passer-by might have thought that some old woman was being murdered in the bushes.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: On that occasion Bashan had stood over the fowl, an utterly bewildered victor, and did not know what to do next.
next_sentence: I hurried up, bent upon preventing something horrible.

question: Things had even [MASK] so far as the christening of the new streets.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Everything had progressed admirably up to a certain point.
next_sentence: For these thoroughfares without inhabitants have right and regular names, just like ordinary or orthodox streets in the city or in the civilised suburbs.

question: In [MASK] we did not like him she would take him back and return the small sum we had paid.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: We were under no obligation at all.
next_sentence: She was not afraid to say thisânot afraid that we might take her at her word.

question: It is edification to the spirit to survey the manifold wild vegetation of the tract and the groves of tiny-leafed trees fettered by their soft dampnessâsweet glimpses which [MASK] and shut in these perspectives.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Nothing could be more grateful to the soul than to ramble through this negligence, this incompletenessâthat is, when one is well and sturdily shod and need not fear the coarse gravel.
next_sentence: Just such a group of trees was painted three hundred years ago by that great master of landscapesâhe who came out of Lorraine.

question: It is characterised by grass mounds which arise at [MASK] and from which telegraph-poles mount into the air.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Alongside the esplanade, nearer to the river, there runs a smaller gravel way which is also overgrown with insurgent shrubbery.
next_sentence: Yet I am fond of frequenting this road on my walks, first because of the change, and second because the gravel permits of clean though somewhat difficult locomotion, when the clayey footpath yonder does not appear passable during days of heavy rain.

question: Even the wild and indiscriminate way in which he wolfed his [MASK], reminded me of his sordid youth.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: On the contrary I was forced to fetch him from his berth at the tiny door of his kennel and to spur him on and up.
next_sentence: And then it was a great joy to see how he found himself again, how his greeting gradually took on the old, warm-hearted, playful impetuosity, how, instead of coming towards me with a sullen limp, he would once more come storming upon me in swift response to my morning whistle, so that he might put his forepaws on my chest and snap at my face.

question: Perhaps the little creatureâs tunnels had not been sunk deep enough, or it had been paralysed by fright and prevented from burrowing to deeper [MASK].
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Perhaps the unfortunate creature had not been properly advised by its instincts of self-preservation and had chosen a spot for its burrow which was too soft, too unprotected and too easily excavated.
next_sentence: Or it had perchance lost its head and, crouching a few inches under the surface with its little beady eyes popping out of their sockets with horror, listened to that terrible snorting coming nearer and nearer.

question: To him my track and trail are as [MASK] as that of a bit of game.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: And so I walk onâuntroubled by any thought that he might not be able to overtake meâeven though he should remain behind for a long time without having observed in what direction I had gone.
next_sentence: Should he have lost sight of me, he is sure, with head lowered between his forepaws, to come tearing along this trail.

question: It offers good walking, thanks to the strip of quay formed of tooled and even stone, which runs along the [MASK] limit of the water.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: It is covered with beach-grass and wild oats as well as with the show-plant of the neighbourhood, the dry, omnipresent blue sage.

question: But [MASK] at the last moment and just before the collision, he manages to put on the brakes and to bring himself toâsomething which testifies to his physical as well as his mental self-control.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Involuntarily I take up a flank position to the charging Bashan as he comes storming onwardâan attitude of defenceâfor his apparent intention of lunging himself between my feet and laying me low is most amazingly deceptive.
next_sentence: And nowâwithout uttering a soundâfor Bashan makes but scant use of his sonorous and expressive voiceâhe begins to carry out a confused dance of welcome and salutation all about me, a dance consisting of rapid tramplings, of prodigious waggingsâwaggings which are not limited to that member which is intended for their proper expressionâbut which demand tribute of his entire hindquarters up to his very ribs, furthermore an annular contraction of his body, as well as darting, far-flung leaps into the air, also rotations about his own axisâperformances which, strange to say, he endeavours to hide from my gaze, for whenever I turn towards him, he transfers them to the other side.

question: And yet it is possible that you are [MASK] a great mistake with regard to the degree of respect which this kind of master would display towards you.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: If so, you had better go to him.
next_sentence: There are, for example, certain fine points and differences for which such gun-bearing persons have a very sharp nose, natural merits or demeritsâor, to make my allusions clearer, very awkward questions regarding pedigree and breed.

question: No, on the contrary, we hunt everything that chances to cross our pathâI had almost said that chances to [MASK] within range of our guns.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Things, to be sure, are not so neatly arranged that Bashan and I could go forth in pursuit of any one special species of the game which I have mentionedâthat we should, for instance, specialise on rabbits or ducks.

question: My sub-intelligence kept scenting out the destroyed name, and [MASK] it shot into my consciousness.

title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: But whilst I thought that I was occupying myself with other things, this particular thing kept working within the mnemonic depths of me.

question: His breathing sounds muffled, he [MASK] his breath in a blast in order to be able to empty his lungs quicklyâand to draw in the delicate, acrid, distant, and yet disguised odour of the mice.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I

question: He continues to [MASK] to me, tightly and helplessly.

question: That is over two years ago and he was only half a [MASK] old at the time.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: HOW WE ACQUIRED BASHAN       CHAPTER II     HOW WE ACQUIRED BASHAN   It was a short, buxom, dark-eyed young woman who, with the help of her equally sturdy and dark-eyed daughter, keeps a hillside tavern not far from the Bavarian mountain resort called Tolz, who acted as go-between in the business of our making Bashanâs acquaintance and then acquiring him.
next_sentence: Anastasiaâthis is the name of mine hostessâknew that we had been compelled to have our Percy shotâhe was a Scotch collie, a harmless, somewhat weak-minded aristocrat, who had been visited in his old age by a painful and disfiguring skin diseaseâand that for over a year we had been without a faithful guardian.

question: Still he refuses to look [MASK], and jogs easily along.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Bashan cannot help hearing all this pother, and he is most disagreeably affected by it, as his guilty and diffident air proclaims.
next_sentence: During this the terrible maledictions to our rear gradually decline in intensity and slowly die away into low whinings and thin yowls.

question: In this [MASK] we hunt: rabbits, quail, field-mice, moles, ducks and gulls.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: That is to say, Bashan goes hunting and I look on.
next_sentence: But we do not by any means fight shy of bigger game; we also track pheasants and even deerâwhenever such first-rate quarryâas sometimes happensâstrays into our hunting-grounds.

question: He knew where we were living, and if he [MASK] it reasonable to sit here still longer and stare, after everything was over and there was absolutely nothing more to see, well that was his own affair.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: I did not again ask him to come alongâI refused to do this as a matter of principle.
next_sentence: It was a long way back, and I, for my part, was going to return.

question: He stands aslant, with his [MASK] paws braced against the ground, his face uplifted towards mine, so that he peers into my eyes from below and in a reversed direction.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: There he stands, like a statue, with his shoulder-blade pressing against my shinbone.
next_sentence: His stillness whilst I pat his shoulder and mutter friendly words, breathes forth the same concentration and emotion as the preceding delirium.

question: This happens, it is true, but it [MASK] only rarely.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: For it is not yet quite impossibleâhowever improbable it may seemâthat I may nevertheless leave the city path at the end of the park, once more turn towards the left and lead him on to libertyâeven if only by way of the slightly roundabout way to the post-box.
next_sentence: Once this hope has dissolved into empty air, Bashan settles down upon his haunches and lets me go my way.

question: But we [MASK] that things being as they were, it was not likely that the matter would have any other outcome.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: It was not that we had already decided upon the acquisition of Lux.
next_sentence: This time we found Anastasia and her daughter sitting opposite each other at the kitchen-table and drinking coffee.

question: The master is captivated by these forays after the wild fowl chiefly in consideration of the landscape, since the friendly nearness of the water is connected with them, but also because it diverts and edifies him to [MASK] the form of life practised by these swimmers and flyers, thus emerging a little out of his own rut and experimenting with theirs.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: This hunt is less exciting than the rabbit hunt is likely to be, but like this it has something that is attractive both to hunter and to hound, or rather to the hunter and his master.
next_sentence: The attitude towards life assumed by the ducks is more amiable, more bourgeois, and more comfortable than that of the gulls.

question: Finally, however, my [MASK] makes use of his liberty and races off.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: They stand thus for a considerable time, and then once more resume their strange and ineffectual race, shoulder to shoulder on either side of the fence.

question: The [MASK] of this syndicate had been dominated by large and lofty ideals.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Building lots were plentiful, for more than a mile down-stream everything had been prepared, and is no doubt still prepared for possible buyers and for lovers of a settled suburban manner of life.
next_sentence: They had not contented themselves with building proper jetties along the banks, with the creation of riverside walks and quays and with the planting of parks and gardens.

question: These, when the afternoon light is fervent and favourable, are even most enchanting to the [MASK].
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: The silver poplar crooks herself wholly in the style of the willow, and it is often difficult to tell her from the birch which, seduced by the genius loci, also frequently affects the most extravagant crookednessesâthough I would not go so far as to say that this dear and friendly tree was not to be found, and numerously found, in exceedingly shapely specimens.
next_sentence: The region knows it as a small silvery trunk with sparse single leaves in the crown, as a sweet grown-up limber virgin with the prettiest of chalky stems and a trim and languishing way of letting the locks of her foliage hang.

question: If we could decide upon [MASK] him at once, it would be a fine thing all round.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: She had at once thought of us, for she knew we were looking for a good dog, and she felt quite certain that we could not help taking him.
next_sentence: She was sure that we would have great joy of him, and as for him, he would no longer be alone in the world, but have a cosy berth, and she, Anastasia, would cease to worry about him.

question: There where the first cross [MASK], running from the avenue of poplars between the meadow ponds and the clumps of trees towards the slope, debouches at the foot of this slope, there is a path that leads towards the left.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: With the charm of its banks of forget-me-nots it forms a counterpart on the hitherside to the zone of the puissant river yonderâthe roar and rushing turbulence of which one is still able to hear in this spotâbut only very faintly and softly and only when the west wind is blowing.
next_sentence: This is used in winter-time as a bob-sled run by the youth of the region, and slants towards the lower-lying levels.

question: Should you leave this road on the right you would be able to reach the [MASK] in a few steps by means of a wagon-road that cuts through the wood.

title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Should you venture over you will set foot upon a road which leads from the village towards the city, running between the edge of the wood and the edge of the meadow.

question: Should you venture over you will [MASK] foot upon a road which leads from the village towards the city, running between the edge of the wood and the edge of the meadow.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: A little foot-bridge crosses the stream.
next_sentence: Should you leave this road on the right you would be able to reach the river in a few steps by means of a wagon-road that cuts through the wood.

question: We follow the tree-lined avenue for about five minutes, to that point where it ceases to be a [MASK] and becomes a coarse desert of gravel parallel to the course of the river.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: To-day you are the man of sobriety and the dew-clad early hour, the right royal lord of that mad hunter yonder who is just making another jump across the fence out of sheer joy that you are apparently content to live this day with him and not waste it upon the world you have left behind you.
next_sentence: We turn our backs upon this and strike into a broad, finely-gravelled street which, like the poplar-lined road, is equipped with a cycle-path, but is still void of houses.

question: For he immediately begins to [MASK] and cavort, as a call to engage in manly enterprises.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: But this soft and timidly lifted paw, this soft, solitary scratching, upon which he had resolved, after all other counsel had failed, work mightily upon me, and I arise to open the door for him in order to let him in, although I know that this can lead to no good.
next_sentence: He pushes the carpet into a hundred folds, spreads confusion through the room, and my peace and quiet are at an end.

question: His head is between his forepaws and thrust into the slant [MASK] he has already dug.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: His small, tiger-striped body beneath the smooth coat of which the ribs align themselves and the muscles play, is hollowed, is concave in the middle; his hindquarters, with the stump of a tail vibrating to quick time, is erected vertically.
next_sentence: With averted face he continues with the rapid strokes of his iron claws to tear up the earth more and moreâlumps of sod, pebbles, shreds of glass, and bits of roots fly all about me.

question: Bashanâs ears are erected, in so far as the muscular structure of flapping [MASK] admits of this.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Under such conditions the tiny secret activities in our immediate world take on a particular importance and preoccupy the senses,âthe brief rustling of a lizard, the note of a bird, the burrowing of a mole in the ground.
next_sentence: He cocks his head in order to intensify his sense of hearing.

question: âThere ought to be more dogsâfive or sixâa whole pack of [MASK]!
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: âItâs no use,â I think, âit may be beautiful, but it is surely futile.â The wild pursuit vanishes in the distances of the park and in the opposite direction.
next_sentence: There ought to be dogs to cut him off on the flank, dogs to cut him off ahead, dogs to drive him into a corner, dogs to be in at the death.â And in my mindâs eye, in my excitement, I behold a whole pack of fox-hounds with lolling tongues go storming upon the rabbit in their midst.

question: In short, he is without [MASK] or dignity, without self-restraint or self-discipline.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: But Bully Bashan begins to shriek and whimper when I merely raise my arm.
next_sentence: But his activities seldom call for armed punitive interventionâthe less so since I have long ago ceased to demand achievements from him which are contrary to his nature and insistence upon which might lead to a collision.

question: The boat bumps against the other bank; the stranger jumps in; upon [MASK] the hither bank he hands the ferryman a nickel coin and leaps up the wooden steps with alacrity.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Without showing the slightest sign of undue haste the ferryman walks with swinging arms through his little garden, crosses the footpath, descends the wooden steps to the river, pushes off the ferry, and holds the rudder whilst the pulley runs along the taut wire, and the boat is driven across by the current.
next_sentence: He has conquered the river, and turns either to the right or to the left.

question: It has a little [MASK] and a hen-house, and is evidently an official dwelling and therefore rent-free.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: The ferryman lives in the ferry-house with his wife and child, and this house lies a short distance from the upper footpath.
next_sentence: It is a kind of villa of liliputian proportions, lightly and whimsically built with little bays and gables, and appears to boast of two rooms below and two above.

question: The region of the [MASK] is arranged and classified as follows: âclose to the edge of the wood there stretches a broad level of gravel.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Here they find their food until the season grows milder and permits them to make their way to the lakes in the hillsâlike the wild and half-wild ducks which also spend the cool and the cold months in the vicinity of the city, balance themselves on the waves, permit themselves to be carried by the current which turns them round and rocks them at will, and then just at the moment when some rapid or whirlpool threatens to engulf them, fly up with light and vibrant wing and settle down once more upon the waterâa little farther up-stream.
next_sentence: This is a continuation of the poplar avenue which I have mentioned so frequently, and runs, say, for about a kilometre down-stream, that is to say, to the little ferrymanâs houseâof which more anon.

question: Who, being free to make his choice, would not follow the course of the [MASK] on his wanderings?
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: But I am also fond of looking upon the brooks of the flatland, whether they be shallow, so as scarcely to cover the polished, silvery, and slippery pebbles of their beds, or as deep as little rivers whichâprotected on both banks by low, overhanging willowsâgo shouldering themselves forward with a vigorous thrust, flowing more swiftly in the middle than at the sides.
next_sentence: The attraction which water exercises upon the normal man is natural and mystically sympathetic.

question: And there he lay down with his paws tucked under him, whilst we [MASK] to the inner rooms and consulted as to the name which he was finally to bear through all the years to come.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: On the other hand, he did not reject the sack which we had stuffed with seaweed and which we had made ready upon the floor for his comfort.
next_sentence: He still refused to eat on the following day.

question: He jumps hither and thither, and the next [MASK], with his nose still glued to the ground, he goes darting off.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: His head lunges forward and to one side, his body stretches and extends itself.
next_sentence: He has struck a scent.

question: He was a stocky, round-bearded and red-cheeked man, wearing a kind of gardenerâs apron, with brown, somewhat bloodshot eyes, the [MASK] and honest glances of which had something astonishingly dog-like in them.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: âIs that one yourn?â asked the attendant who, implements in hand, had in the meantime approached me.
next_sentence: I answered his question in the affirmative, referred to the order I had received to call again to-day, to the telephone conversations I had carried on, and declared that I had come to see how everything stood.

question: Thus they shove and slink towards each other, side by side, [MASK] and full of a troubled watchfulness, flank to flank, and begin to snuffle at each otherâs hides.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: They would like to be free of all this; they turn away their heads, squint sadly aside.
next_sentence: It is during this procedure that the growlings begin.

question: But the dog was there to be observed and he was being [MASK].
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: No, one didnât know anything about it as yet.
next_sentence: The hemorrhages were still occurring, were they?

question: They have stood here far too long, giving a name to adumbrations of streets in which no one cares to live, and they have been singled out to bear the [MASK] of disappointment, fiasco, and arrested development to which they give public expression.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: These shields, alas, are not in the best condition.
next_sentence: They are wrapped in an air of forlorn disquietude and neglect.

question: He then lies down once more, being careful, however, to [MASK] his contact with my foot.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: And the nostrils of his moist black nose are in incessant and sensitive motion, responsive to innumerable subtle reactions.
next_sentence: He is lying in a profile position, in the ancient, well-proportioned, animalistic, idol-like attitude of the sphinx, with elevated head and breast, his thighs pressed close to his body, his paws extended in front of him.

question: No one [MASK] my right to go into the house or into the park, just as the spirit moved me.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: No one came with paw hesitatingly raised, so that, giving way to a burst of pitying laughter, I should be forced to deny my own fixed resolution and go forth earlier than I had intended.
next_sentence: This was a comfortable condition of things, quieting and full of the charm of novelty.

question: In this position his figure [MASK] smaller and stockier than it really is, and the white whorl of hair upon his chest is thrust into comic prominence.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: His manner of sitting is a bit peasant-like, a bit uncouthâwith his shoulder-blades turned outward and his paws turned in, irregularly.
next_sentence: But his head is thrown back in the most dignified manner and redeems his disregard for a fine pose by virtue of the intense concentrated attention it displays.

question: He lay behind the bars of his cage upon some loose stuff which must have been made of tan-bark or something similar, and which added its own [MASK] aroma to the odour of the animals and of the carbolic acid or lysoform.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: My first survey of the scene, whilst the door was still open, had at once revealed to me the whereabouts of Bashan, and so I went up to him.
next_sentence: He lay there like a leopard, though a very weary, very disinterested and disappointed leopard.

question: We found her in her roomy [MASK] which was filled with warm and succulent vapours.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: The children coaxed and urged, and as the curiosity of their elders was scarcely less than their own, we all sallied forth the very next afternoon to climb the heights where Anastasiaâs tavern lay.
next_sentence: There she stood with her round bare forearms and her dress open at the throat, with her face rosy and shiny, preparing the evening meal for her boarders, whilst her daughter, busily but quietly going to and fro, lent assistance.

question: It is a favourite hiding-place for pheasants and quail, and the vegetation runs in [MASK] against the gnarled boles of the tree-roots.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Sometimes it degenerates into reeds, whilst in other parts it is soft, thick, and lush, mixed with hemlock, nettles, coltâs foot, all manner of creeping, leafy stuff, high, rocket-like thistles, and young and tender tree-shoots.
next_sentence: Out of this chaos of undergrowth and ground thicket the wild vine and the wild hop-plant go gyrating up in spirals, draping broad-leaved garlands upon the trees and even in winter clinging to the trunks with tendrils which resemble hard and unbreakable wire.

question: But it stretches one of its boughs longingly towards the brook and has really succeeded in reaching the flowing [MASK] with the silvery foliage that plumes the tip of this bough.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: It growsâI had almost said she growsâclose to the bluff, and thus at some distance from the water.
next_sentence: There it stands, with fay-like fingers wet in the stream and draws pleasure from the contact.

question: In a moment both of them are merely a tangle, a raving, chaotic tumult out of which arise [MASK] gutteral cries, as of dragons of the prime tearing each other.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: But the battle of bites, of tooth and claw, is upon usâin a flashâno one could say how or why.
next_sentence: In order to avert a tragedy I am forced to interpose my stick, to seize Bashan by his collar or by the scruff of his neck, and to hoist him into the air with one arm with his antagonist hanging to him with locked jawsâor face whatever other terrors may be awaiting meâterrors which I am then fated to feel in every nerve during the greater part of the walk.

question: And so we descended to the valley, thoughtfully [MASK] and ruminating upon our impressions.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: We finally begged leave to be permitted to consider the matter for a short time, and this was graciously granted us.
next_sentence: That bit of four-legged misery under the table had naturally captured the hearts of the children, and we grown-ups attempted in vain to smile away their lack of taste and judgment.

question: Sometimes its course will be a mere green flowing tunnel with the rocks scarcely covered and with the gulls appearing to [MASK] stilt-legged on the very surface itself.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: The stream behaves like all other members of its family, the small as well as the smallest, that is to say, according to the weather and the water conditions in the upper mountain regions.
next_sentence: And then, again, it will assume a most formidable character, swelling into a wide stream, filling its bed with gray watery fury and tumult, and bearing along in its headlong course all kinds of unseemly objects such as old baskets, pieces of wooden crates, bushes, and dead cats in its circling wrath, and showing a great disposition to flooding and to deeds of violence.

question: The trees in our hunting-grounds are of [MASK] ages and circumference.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: There can be no talk of a wood in the usual sense of the termâa kind of great pillared grove with moss and strewn leafage and tree-trunks of fairly uniform girth.
next_sentence: Huge patriarchs of the willow and poplar families are to be found among them, especially along the river, though they are also to be encountered in the inner woods.

question: As to the soilâthis has little [MASK] to that of a forest.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: But it also makes its appearance as a creature of absolutely elephantine proportions with a waist which no man could span with his arms and a rind which has preserved traces of its erstwhile whiteness only high up towards the top, whilst near the ground it has become a coarse, calcined and fissured bark.
next_sentence: It is pebbly, full of clay and even sand, and no one would dream of calling it fertile.

question: He is absolutely certain that his bit of game is sitting there under the earth in some snug runlet or [MASK]; all that is necessary is to get at it, and so he goes digging away for all he is worth in absolute devotion to his task and oblivious to the world.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: But did not my Bashan hear the quarry, scent it, perhaps even see it as it switched away?
next_sentence: He proceeds not ragingly, but with a certain fine deliberation, with the tempered passion of the real sportsmanâit is wonderful to see.

question: The level cataracts are rushing and roaring all around, and halfway to the ferrymanâs houseâthe voice of a waterfall joins the chorusâfrom over yonder where the canal, debouching at a [MASK], pours itself into a river.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: There is no lack of surgings, even if there is of surges, nor of the clamour of gulls, nor of that kind of space-annihilating monotony which lulls one into a sort of narcotic absentmindedness.
next_sentence: The body of this fall is arched, smooth, glassy like that of a fish, and an everlasting boiling tumult goes on at its base.

question: But it is not at all necessary to comfort him; his failure does not depress him for a [MASK].
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: âNothing doing,â I repeat, shaking my head and raising my brows and my shoulders, so as to make the message plainer.
next_sentence: To hunt is to hunt, the titbit of game is the least of all considerations.

question: Our [MASK] preserved him from this sinister destiny.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: During this period it was necessary to keep a sharp eye on him whilst out walking, for he was all too prone to tear asunder unperceived the weak band of sympathy that bound us, and in a grand burst of independent living to lose himself in the woodsâwhere he would certainly have reverted to the condition of his savage forbears.
next_sentence: We strove to keep him on that high moral level which his kind had achieved at the side of man during thousands of years of association in common.

question: He was also unspoiled and very [MASK] in his demandsâsomething which was worth a good deal in such lean times as these.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: She, Anastasia, would guarantee that his points were all good.
next_sentence: Up to the present he had supported himself entirely on potato-skins.

question: He seemed to be oppressed by a [MASK] of dark hopelessnessâand contempt.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: But he was as little affected by my going away as by my coming.
next_sentence: âSince you have been capable,â his attitude seemed to declare, âof having me put into this cage, I expect nothing more from you.â And was it not in truth enough to make him despair of all reason and justice?

question: He still [MASK] to eat on the following day.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: And there he lay down with his paws tucked under him, whilst we retired to the inner rooms and consulted as to the name which he was finally to bear through all the years to come.
next_sentence: Then followed a period during which he devoured indiscriminately everything that came within the radius of his jaws, until he attained the necessary degree of quiet regularity and critical dignity in matters of diet.

question: But he went slinking at my heels with silly [MASK] and lolling tongue, and the pheasants were jubilant over a close season.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: I took him to the hunting-grounds on the very first day of his home-coming.
next_sentence: At home he would remain lying for days as I had last seen him stretched out in his cage at the hospital, and staring with glassy eyes, inwardly limp and without a trace of his wholesome impatience, without making a single attempt to force me to go forth for a walk.

question: Farther on the brook, in [MASK] its course towards the setting sun, reaches a small hamlet which commands a view towards the northâbetween the woods and the slopeâand at the entrance to this hamlet lies the tavern.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Under no conditions will he tolerate any interference with anything that appears to him natural, inevitable, and according to the fitness of things.
next_sentence: Here the brook once more broadens into a pond.

question: It was clear that if our good man was not merely concerned with having made a good pot-shot and a killing, but also with a more [MASK] purpose, then he would be obliged to put his best leg forward.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Nevertheless the carcass of the duck had been seized at once by the current, whirled about its axis and was beginning to float off.
next_sentence: This he did without losing a momentâeverything happened with immense rapidity.

question: We were given a pleasant greeting, and the fact that we had not postponed our visit but had come to attend to business without [MASK], was favourably commented upon.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: There she stood with her round bare forearms and her dress open at the throat, with her face rosy and shiny, preparing the evening meal for her boarders, whilst her daughter, busily but quietly going to and fro, lent assistance.
next_sentence: In answer to our inquisitive glances, Resi, the daughter, steered us toward the kitchen table.

question: Here and there the slope [MASK] offers one the use of wooden steps, half ladders and half stairs, by means of which one may, with a fair degree of comfort, descend into the actual river-bed, which is usually quite dry.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: It is protected by ingenious works of woven willow-withes and by a concrete armour along its lower parts against the mounting flood water which once or twice a year comes rolling hitherâwhen the snows melt in the mountains or the rain overdoes itself.
next_sentence: It is the reserve gravel bed of the big wild brook, and is about six metres wide.

question: The smell of the dog-hospital which he had brought with him, vanished in the [MASK] trays, after several ablutions with soap and hot waterâvanishedâall save a few floating and rebellious whiffs.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: Perhaps I ought to say that he was only the shadow of himselfâif this would not be an insult to the proud and joyous Bashan.
next_sentence: A bath may be said to exercise a spiritual influence, may be said to possess a symbolic significance to us human beingsâbut no one would dare to say that the physical cleansing of poor Bashan, meant the restoration of his customary spirits.

question: No longer, however, as in [MASK] times, does he hollow his hands into a trumpet and shout through them.
source_info: Bashan and I by Thomas, Paul
title: Bashan and I
prev_sentence: A man appears on the other bank, stands still and peers across the water.

question: Und als es fertig war, siehe, da war es auch [MASK].

prev_sentence: Es wurde vielleicht nicht gut, aber es wurde fertig.

question: Versagen und verzagen--das [MASK]'s, was uebrigblieb.
source_info: Gladius Dei; Schwere Stunde by Mann, Paul Thomas
title: Gladius Dei; Schwere Stunde
prev_sentence: Und so war es, dies war die verzweifelte Wahrheit: Die Jahre der Not und der Nichtigkeit, die er fuer Leidens- und Pruefungsjahre gehalten, sie eigentlich waren reiche und fruchtbare Jahre gewesen; und nun, da ein wenig Glueck sich herniedergelassen, da er aus dem Freibeutertum des Geistes in einige Rechtlichkeit und buergerliche Verbindung eingetreten war, Amt und Ehren trug, Weib und Kinder besass, nun war er erschoepft und fertig.
